David Christofferson
member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints · Author has 1.9K answers and 1.9M answer views · Feb 2 ·

Question: Do you think it’s fair for the LDS church not to allow the father of the bride to witness her temple marriage because he can’t qualify for a temple recommend?

It is amazing to me how many questions I see where the answer reflects a conversation I’ve recently had with my 6 year old. When he doesn’t get his way or is told “no,” he will often bemoan how unfair our decision is. Because he doesn’t know what “fair” means. What he is actually saying is he doesn’t like that he isn’t getting his way, because he wants to do what he wants with no consequences.

What does “fair” mean:

impartial and just, without favoritism or discrimination

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has extremely clear standards for what it takes to go to the temple. One must be recommended as someone worthy to enter by both their bishopric and stake presidency. To determine worthiness, the individual sits down for an interview with a member of each group and is asked a set of standard questions. Receiving a recommend is entirely based on if you are actually living according to those questions. For example: “do you obey the Law of Chastity” or “are you honest in your dealings with your fellow man?”

Every single person who has a temple recommend has one because they are living according to the same impartial standard. No one is discriminated against for any reason. If you are living in accordance with the standards set by the temple recommend interview questions, you may enter the temple. If you are not, you cannot. This process is by definition, fair.

Further: weddings, especially temple weddings, aren’t sudden. At least, not sudden enough that this would normally be something sprung on a parent last minute. If you are a member of the Church, you know what the standard is to enter the temple. If you are not a member (but your child getting married is, because that is how they can enter the temple), then I do apologize that your child decided not to tell you this until the last minute apparently.

Feelings aside, the one thing this process is not is unfair. It would be highly discriminatory and showing favoritism to allow this one individual in who doesn’t qualify and to not let in the other billions of individuals who also don’t currently qualify.

I quite truly am sorry you find yourself in this situation. But exactly like I tell my six year old: just because you don’t like it, doesn’t mean it isn’t fair.

What documents should we check before buying any land?

Once you decide to buy a plot, make sure you have all documents in place. Without these, your purchase will be delayed. Having all the proper legal documentation will help protect your land and home from any disputes in the future. Consult a lawyer to help you with every step of the documentation process.

Most of the required documents can be grouped into two types - legal and personal.

Legal documents: These documents are essential, and missing even one of these can result in a delay in purchase.

They include: -

Mother Deed: This is taken from the seller. The Mother Deed is the main document to determine ownership of the property. It traces the land’s chain of ownership and provides information about the history of the plot.

Sales Deed: The Sales Deed records the transfer of land ownership from the seller to the buyer. You can get it validated at the sub-registrar's office.

Power of Attorney(POA): If the seller of the land is not the owner, they should have a Power of Attorney that authorizes them to sell the plot. Always check the Power of Attorney when buying from any seller.

Encumbrance Certificate: An Encumbrance Certificate documents all the transactions related to the land. It serves as proof that the land you are buying is free of any monetary or legal bindings. It is obtained from the sub-registrar’s office where land is registered.

Katha certificate: A Khata Certificate is necessary to obtain a building license. It contains property details like location, size, built-up area etc. and is necessary for the payment of property tax and to obtain a building license. It is obtained from the Assistant Revenue Officer.

Land Clearance: If you wish to convert agricultural land to non-agricultural land this certificate becomes very essential.

Record Of Rights (ROR) certificate: It is obtained from the Tehsildar’s office

Personal documents: Personal documents are purely for verification purposes: Aadhar, Voter ID card and PAN card.

Things to keep in mind:

In case the seller is not the owner, check the ‘power of attorney’ document.

To make sure measurements mentioned by seller are accurate, get a survey sketch of the land from Survey Department.

If there are more than one owner, make sure to get ‘release certificate’ from all owners.

Sure. The same way that a private club might deny entrance to that person if they don’t have an invitation if the wedding were held there. Or if someone was invited to a destination wedding but couldn’t afford to get there. This happens. A lot.

There are lots of reasons parents miss their children’s weddings. They might be in jail. They might be estranged. They might be from different faiths with strong opinions about that. Who hasn’t heard about the parents who refused to attend their child’s LGBT ceremony? Society tends to view these as “acceptable” reasons for missing a wedding. But add a church into the question and people are supposed to say, “Oh, well, that’s different?” No. No it isn’t. The church doesn’t decide who gets to go and who doesn’t. The wedding couple makes that decision.

The wedding couple chose where to have their wedding. They invited those who could be there and did not invite those who could not. The parent was not invited. End of discussion and no, the parent doesn’t have a say. This isn’t their wedding day, it’s their child’s. Spare us from parents who act like entitled little brats when their children do things that exclude them.

In years past, this did lead to some strife and bad feelings between family members in this church. Partly, that was because, in America, at least, if you chose to have a wedding outside the temple, you were required to wait a year before a sealing ritual could be performed. Interestingly, this was not the case in the UK, where civil ceremonies were required to be performed outside of the temple by law and the church accommodated by allowing sealings shortly thereafter. In recent years, the church has modified its policies around the world so that weddings are performed outside the temple and only the ritual of sealing is performed in the temple as it has been in the UK. Therefore, this question is now moot.

Twenty-two years ago, my wife and I were married in the temple at 6:20 a.m. in a packed room filled with family and friends. Her atheist family: mother, father, and sister arrived after the ceremony and joined us outside the temple for a ring ceremony which they were able to be a part of. Nobody felt left out and the wedding couple had discussed this with their parents so everyone felt included. As the years went by, her relationship with her parents and sister improved, rather than deteriorated. When her dad passed a couple of years ago, it shook everyone in our family, even me. You don’t get there without a lot of love and caring—none of it lost because those parents weren’t physically in that room at that moment.

What happens when you are married/sealed in the Mormon temple?
Originally Answered: What happens when you are sealed in the Mormon temple?

OK, none of these answers have truly answered the question.

When a couple is sealed in a temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the groom kneels on one side of the altar, and the bride on the other. They join hands over the altar. The officiator asks the groom if this is of his own free will and accord, and then asks the bride the same question.

Having received an affirmative answer from both, the officiator says that he pronounces them husband and wife for time and for all eternity. He then adds a couple more paragraphs about the blessings they will receive in the next life, and what their obligations are to each other in this life. He concludes by using his authority in the priesthood in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost.

Generally, the couple will kiss over the altar at that point and then greet their friends. If rings are to be exchanged they may do so at this point or wait until the reception when others can witness this. The ceremony takes about five minutes. The ceremony is also preceded by the officiator giving a (hopefully) short talk about matrimony and its meaning in the temple. You can see pictures of sealing rooms on Google.

No, it is not an “official doctrine” but the understanding that God produces men and women after His likeness suggests there is a woman god that works with Him to produce children in the normal way. And what is wrong with that? God designated that the man must not be without the woman and the woman without the man in marriage, which He instituted with Adam and Eve. God keeps His commandments better than we can. It is logical that there be a Mother if there is a Father. Jesus did have a mortal Mother. He wasn’t born of a man. Seems they have as specialized a duty as a man does. And the great commandment was to ‘multiply’ and replenish the earth. Seems also that is what God is all about, giving life.

What is official doctrine is the commandment from Jesus (and by extension His Father and our Father), that we worship the Father only and do so in the name of Jesus Christ, our advocate to the Father. Per Jesus, it doesn’t matter what or how many other Gods there actually are, there is only one God to whom we must serve and worship and no other besides Him.

If you dig back in ancient times the Jews had an idea that there was a female god. They were corrected about worshiping Her as well.

What happens in the temple at a Mormon wedding?

There's some excellent stuff put out by the church on sealing ceremonies on their website: lds.org. I can't link to it directly right now.

Instead, I'll tell you what happened at mine, which is indicative of all of them:

We got to the temple at 530 in the morning on Saturday, because we were among the first weddings of the day at 620. Our invited guests had to be there at 600! The fact that we filled the 50-chair room is a testament to the many people who love us, family and friends.

In the sealing room is an altar, covered in soft pillows for comfort. We kneel facing each other, take each other's hands, and listen to the Sealer, who officiates the service. We consenting to the binding, and that's it. There were hugs and kisses and we were being gently directed out so the next party could come in.

Outside the temple, we gathered for pictures, and, as my in-laws were not members of the church and thus missed the ceremony inside, we held a ring ceremony there with them, because we wanted to include them in the ceremonies. The pictures are lovely.

I don't mean to make it seem boring, but, well, it is functional, not spectacle. Whatever spectacle there is involved the infinity mirrors and the lovely decorations inn the room, but mostly our beaming smiles.

Has the LDS Church tried to buy the Kirtland Temple?

Original question: Has the LDS Church tried to buy the Kirtland Temple?

Neither The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints or the Community of Christ have made any such efforts public, but I’m sure it has been discussed. We have the resources to properly maintain the Temple. The Temple is less relevant to the Community of Christ than it was in decades past, and it is very possible that such talks will take place in the future. But we don’t know.

If such a purchase ever happens I would be great, but it is not essential to our doctrine. We make use of the Temple from time to time for meetings

Original question: Has the LDS Church tried to buy the Kirtland Temple?

Neither The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints or the Community of Christ have made any such efforts public, but I’m sure it has been discussed. We have the resources to properly maintain the Temple. The Temple is less relevant to the Community of Christ than it was in decades past, and it is very possible that such talks will take place in the future. But we don’t know.

If such a purchase ever happens I would be great, but it is not essential to our doctrine. We make use of the Temple from time to time for meetings, youth conferences, and such. With the warm relations that now exist between the two churches, we would probably assist in the maintenance and upkeep of the Temple if we were asked (and it is possible that we do that now, but if we do, it is not something we draw attention to).

I’m just grateful that the former RLDS church has kept that building safe and intact over the years. To former RLDS and the current leadership of the Community of Christ, we owe a debt of gratitude. And not only for the Kirkland Temple, but other sacred historical sites as well.

Does the LDS Church allow members to marry non-members in the temple?

Temple marriage is eternal marriage. It is only eternal marriage if you accept and living according to the covenants that make eternal marriage possible. And the God-given authority to perform an eternal marriage is only binding if the parties involved truly believe that said authority exists. So it doesn’t make sense for someone who is not a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to even want to get married in the temple.

Members of the Church can absolutely get married to non-members outside of the temple. If said non-members would like to turn that into an eternal marriage, they will need to commit to the covenants that lead to that.

Are LDS temples doing endowments?

Most temples are in phase III of reopening. This means that work for the dead at the temples is being performed, but only by appointment and at reduced capacity.

I am an ordinance worker at the Jordan River Utah Temple. For the next few weeks, sessions are capped at 38 patrons per session. This is about 30% capacity. The ordinance rooms at this temple have seats for 125 patrons. We are hopeful that we will be able to go back to 55% capacity or 75 patrons per session. In fact, we are hopeful to be one day going back to full capacity. We also had 30% of our workers on my shift out sick this last week.

At this capacity, and I have seen this when we were at 55%, it is possible for some families to take the session themselves when someone is going through for their own endowment. I would recommend that all perspective missionaries schedule their endowment as soon as the Stake President signs their mission papers.

If an LDS woman marries someone who isn't LDS, can she still be sealed in the temple with him after he converts?

Original question: If an LDS woman marries someone who isn't LDS, can she still be sealed in the temple with him after he converts?

If he converts, that means he is a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, with all the privileges and responsibilities as any other member. As a member, he may apply for a temple recommend. So yes, and I know quite a few people who have done it like that.

How do Mormons get married if they don't have a church or temple?

They go anywhere that does weddings.

Members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints have no theology about it being better to get married in one of their churches, like they do about getting married in a temple. If you can’t go to the temple for some reason, including that one is inaccessible to you, there is no eternal difference, no cultural expectation even, between getting married at one of our chapels and any other legal wedding venue, whether a park or a ship or courthouse. Those who are married civilly simply go to the temple later.

Are those who are not LDS allowed to enter temples?

Visitors are welcome in our regular meetinghouses. Services start at 9:00 am Sunday. Show up and we’ll happily guide you through our worship.

But our temples, like the temples of the Old and New Testament, are not open to the general public most times, because they are dedicated places of holiness.

Let's look at this logically:

The temple is the dedicated house of the Lord. Do you allow just anyone to go through your house? Don't we usually allow only those with the keys to unlock the door to enter? And we give keys to those we trust to protect and use the house according to our desires?

There is

Visitors are welcome in our regular meetinghouses. Services start at 9:00 am Sunday. Show up and we’ll happily guide you through our worship.

But our temples, like the temples of the Old and New Testament, are not open to the general public most times, because they are dedicated places of holiness.

Let's look at this logically:

The temple is the dedicated house of the Lord. Do you allow just anyone to go through your house? Don't we usually allow only those with the keys to unlock the door to enter? And we give keys to those we trust to protect and use the house according to our desires?

There is nothing that precludes anyone from doing what is required to gain that trust and earn the key, one requirement of which is joining the church. But those who have not are not welcome except at those times known as “Open houses,” which are relatively rare and occur before the dedication.

It is the same in our own homes as it is with God.

Search engines are your friend, everyone (unless it's Google). I got this from https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/ensign/2020/01/aus-eng-local-pages/local-news-002?lang=eng. Language is quoted starting in the next paragraph. Please note that this language does change, as it did in 2020. The interviewer should stick to the wording exactly as given, and it is discouraged to ask follow up questions (correct me if I'm wrong in the comments).

  1. Do you have faith in and a testimony of God, the Eternal Father; His Son, Jesus Christ; and the Holy Ghost?
  2. Do you have a testimony of the Atonement of Jesus Christ and of His role as your Savior and Redeemer?
  3. Do you have a testimony of the Restoration of the gospel of Jesus Christ?
  4. Do you sustain the president of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints as the prophet, seer, and revelator and as the only person on the earth authorized to exercise all priesthood keys? Do you sustain the members of the First Presidency and the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles as prophets, seers, and revelators? Do you sustain the other General Authorities and local leaders of the Church?
  5. The Lord has said that all things are to be “done in cleanliness” before Him (Doctrine and Covenants 42:41). Do you strive for moral cleanliness in your thoughts and behavior? Do you obey the law of chastity?
  6. Do you follow the teachings of the Church of Jesus Christ in your private and public behavior with members of your family and others?
  7. Do you support or promote any teachings, practices, or doctrine contrary to those of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints?
  8. Do you strive to keep the Sabbath day holy, both at home and at church; attend your meetings; prepare for and worthily partake of the sacrament; and live your life in harmony with the laws and commandments of the gospel?
  9. Do you strive to be honest in all that you do?
  10. Are you a full-tithe payer?
  11. Do you understand and obey the Word of Wisdom?
  12. Do you have any financial or other obligations to a former spouse or to children? If yes, are you current in meeting those obligations?
  13. Do you keep the covenants that you made in the temple, including wearing the temple garment as instructed in the endowment?
  14. Are there serious sins in your life that need to be resolved with priesthood authorities as part of your repentance?
  15. Do you consider yourself worthy to enter the Lord’s house and participate in temple ordinances?

Do Mormons have to go through the temple before they can be sealed in marriage? Do other churches do this as well?

Original question: Do Mormons have to go through the temple before they can be sealed in marriage? Do other churches do this as well?

Informed and unbigoted people no longer call us “Mormons,” but rather our real name, which is Latter-day Saints.

The sealing ordinance only takes place inside the temple. So you have to enter the temple to be sealed.

To be sealed to a spouse, you must have first received the endowment, which is also available only inside the temple. To be sealed to a parent, no endowment is required.

Original question: Do Mormons have to go through the temple before they can be sealed in marriage? Do other churches do this as well?

Informed and unbigoted people no longer call us “Mormons,” but rather our real name, which is Latter-day Saints.

The sealing ordinance only takes place inside the temple. So you have to enter the temple to be sealed.

To be sealed to a spouse, you must have first received the endowment, which is also available only inside the temple. To be sealed to a parent, no endowment is required.

I am not aware of any other denomination that has a concept analogous to eternal family relationships. Mainstream Christians have condemned us as heretics for such beliefs.

Have you heard of SEALING of marriage/families in Mormonism?

Q: Have you heard of SEALING of marriage/families in Mormonism?

A: Yes, but I am a member of The Church, we literally don’t shut up about it, the idea is even taught in the little kid Sunday school classes (Which we call Primary). Asking if you ever heard of SEALING in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is kind of like asking if you ever heard of THE VIRGIN MARY in Catholicism.

I specify The Church of Jesus Christ of later-day Saints because when someone mentions Mormonism they usually mean us, or are conflating other groups with us. Some of the break off groups do not practice sealing, or don’t believe in it at all.

For those who don’t know Sealing is how familial/marital relationships can be taken beyond the grave, this is opposed to traditional Christian thought, which is that those relationships dissolve and are replaced with our connection to Christ (This isn’t to say, according to traditional thought, we don’t get to see our family in heaven, but that our relationships with them aren’t husband/wife, parent/child relationships). Our belief is that we can have a relationship with Christ and with our families/spouses.

Can people who have been previously married attend weddings in an LDS Temple (Mormon)?

The only requirement to being able to attend a temple wedding is for someone to have a current temple recommend and have been endowed. Having been divorced is not a disqualifier from holding a recommend.

If a member leaves the LDS Church, do they lose their temple recommend?

Temple recommends are only valid for 2 years. Even if no action is taken by the bishop, they will not be usable shortly after someone decides they are leaving the Church. In most cases, people just stop coming out, as opposed to making a big deal about their departure. When this happens, by the time it’s clear they are not coming back anytime soon, the recommend will have already expired. If someone were to leave and make known their intentions, the bishop could ask for their recommend or simply deactivate it in the system. The Church has moved on to an electronic system with recommends where you scan it in at the temple to check in. Local leadership has the ability to deactivate recommends when it’s clear someone is no longer eligible to go to the temple.

What is the purpose of temples in the LDS Church?

Biblical religion has always had two aspects of worship: there is the common worship done in the chapel/synagogue/meetinghouse, and there is the worship done only in the temple. In biblical times, only those who made certain covenants with God were allowed to enter the temple.

Today, this aspect of biblical religion has largely been lost to the world. Christians and Jews alike have largely lost the sense that temples are even a part of their religion. Christians will say that the coming of Christ made temples obsolete, but that is not true. Christ put an end to blood sacrifice and certain aspec

Biblical religion has always had two aspects of worship: there is the common worship done in the chapel/synagogue/meetinghouse, and there is the worship done only in the temple. In biblical times, only those who made certain covenants with God were allowed to enter the temple.

Today, this aspect of biblical religion has largely been lost to the world. Christians and Jews alike have largely lost the sense that temples are even a part of their religion. Christians will say that the coming of Christ made temples obsolete, but that is not true. Christ put an end to blood sacrifice and certain aspects of Levitical tradition, but He did not put an end to temple worship. This is why the Apostles continued to worship at the temple even after Christ’s ascension. It is also why John speaks of temple worship still to occur near the end times.

Today, in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, temple worship exists for the purpose of allowing people who have entered into the covenant of baptism to make and keep further covenants with God and help others to do the same.

Do all Mormons have temple weddings? Are temple weddings required for Mormons who wish to get married? What happens if a Mormon is going to marry a non-Mormon?

Members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints can marry where, when, and whom they wish. Many faithful Latter-day Saints (we prefer that to Mormons) do get married in the temple, especially in the United States.

However, a temple marriage is really two ceremonies in one. In the United States, the government allows ministers to perform weddings. Members of the Church who wish to marry in the temple have to get a license from the appropriate authority, bring it to the temple, and then are married and “sealed” together for eternity. This ceremony is required for those who wish their union to endure throughout eternity. (I should say that the ceremony is exactly the same, no matter where the civil part is taking place).

Members outside the United States may not have the ability to get married by ministers. Many countries in Europe do not allow this. And many American couples may have non-member friends or relatives who cannot go into the temple, as good standing in Church membership is required.
